div.p: TINTERTEXTUALITY belongs conceptually to WRITING TEXTUALFEATURES . It provides a place to talk about all those textual markers that acknowledge the existence of or imply a relation with other texts. It encloses a statement, nearly always including an author’s name and/or a title. (If you want your prose to feature title, not author, tag the title and insert an empty Name tag with Standard attribute filled in.) This tag has no mandatory or optional sub-elements but it has two optional attributes: INTERTEXTTYPE and GENDEROFAUTHOR. The attribute INTERTEXTTYPE has values of allusionAcknowledged, allusionUnacknowledged, quotation, misquotation, parody, satire, imitation, adaptation-update, prequel, continuation, answer. The attribute GENDEROFAUTHOR has values of male or female.

div.codeblock: <TINTERTEXTUALITY INTERTEXTTYPE="allusionAcknowledged" genderOfAuthor=male>Elizabeth Cellier cites Exodus 1. 15-21, where midwives defy Pharoah's orders to murder men children. </TINTERTEXTUALITY>
<TINTERTEXTUALITY INTERTEXTTYPE="answer" genderOfAuthor=male>Elizabeth Cobbold's poem is an answer to The Sovereign, a poem by Charles Small Pybus.</TINTERTEXTUALITY>

div.p: When encountering a film adaptation of a woman writer's work, use NONBOOKMEDIA. The TINTERTEXUTALITY tag with attribute adaptation/update is for adaptations of other people’s work made by the subject of the entry.
